results.title: Working
results.creator_credit: Alasdair Clayre, Nigel Houghton, Patrick Lui and Peter Montagnon
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Heart of the Dragon”.
This program is Part Six of a twelve episode documentary, The Heart of the Dragon. The documentary records what is actually happening in China today and it captures on film the lives of peasants, factory workers, Party officials, artists, scientists, and even millionaires.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alasdair Clayre, Nigel Houghton, Patrick Lui and Peter Montagnon

results.title: Correcting
results.creator_credit: Alasdair Clayre, Nigel Houghton, Patrick Lui and Peter Montagnon
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Heart of the Dragon”.
This program follows the trial of Nie Chengying, accused of stealing from her neighbour, to show the legal system at work in China. The legal system not only aims to punish and protect society, but also seeks to restore the social harmony which has been disturbed by the crime. Also explores the social pressures at work in the new consumer society which may cause a person to commit a crime.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alasdair Clayre, Nigel Houghton, Patrick Lui and Peter Montagnon

results.title: Eating
results.creator_credit: Alasdair Clayre, Nigel Houghton, Patrick Lui and Peter Montagnon
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Heart of the Dragon”.
This program contrasts food habits and agricultural conditions in China and considers how long China can continue to support a population which, despite birth control, continues to grow at an alarming rate.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alasdair Clayre, Nigel Houghton, Patrick Lui and Peter Montagnon

results.title: Caring
results.creator_credit: Alasdair Clayre, Nigel Houghton, Patrick Lui and Peter Montagnon
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Heart of the Dragon”.
This program visits Minus Eighteen Street in northern Harbin (Ha-erh-pin) to examine urban life in China, using the family of a railway policeman as an example. Also looks at institutions for those with whom the community cannot cope. Highlights how life is governed by concepts of honour, moral conduct, courtesy and respectful behaviour which are deep rooted in Chinese society.

results.title: Remembering
results.creator_credit: Alasdair Clayre, Nigel Houghton, Patrick Lui and Mischa Scorer
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Heart of the Dragon”.
This series documents the historical and cultural traditions of China, showing how attitudes in China today are shaped not only by the doctrines of Marx and Mao but also by ancient beliefs and traditions and by the living memories of recent cataclysmic events. This program seeks to identify what it is that unifies a quarter of the world’s population. Uses both original footage and archive material to give a broad overview of historic and modern China.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alasdair Clayre, Nigel Houghton, Patrick Lui and Mischa Scorer

group_works.title: Confusion: diagnosis and management
group_works.creator_credit: Scottish Health Education Unit and Sidhartha Films

results.title: Confusion: diagnosis and management
results.creator_credit: Scottish Health Education Unit and Sidhartha Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Health education and the elderly”.
One in a series about techniques for the management and treatment of confusion in the elderly. This episode looks in some detail, at the various causes of acute confusion, outlining the basic principles of treatment.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Scottish Health Education Unit and Sidhartha Films

results.title: Confusion
results.creator_credit: Scottish Health Education Unit and Sidhartha Films
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Health education and the elderly”.
An elderly woman is found ill and confused by her neighbour. We follow the process of hospital admission through her eyes. The film stresses the importance of correct initial diagnosis and the importance of sympathetic attitudes from medical staff.
